description:
Aspergillus japonicus CBS 114.51 is a filamentous fungus that belongs to the genus Aspergillus. It is a member of the Aspergillus section Nigri, which is known for its black-colored spores. The species was originally isolated in Japan, hence the name "japonicus."

A. japonicus CBS 114.51 is a common environmental fungus that can be found in soil, decaying plant matter, and various other substrates. It is known to produce various secondary metabolites, including mycotoxins, which can have potential implications in food and feed safety.

Morphologically, A. japonicus CBS 114.51 produces dark-colored conidiophores (asexual reproductive structures) and round to globose black-colored conidia (asexual spores). The fungus can grow at a wide range of temperatures, typically between 20-37Â°C, and can tolerate moderate levels of osmotic stress and pH variations.

Genetically, the species has been studied extensively, and its genome has been sequenced, providing insights into its evolutionary relationships, metabolic capabilities, and potential applications in various industrial and biotechnological processes.
